hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the matrix. Each element can either be a 0 or a 1. Your goal is to find the longest line of consecutive 1s in any direction: horizontal, vertical, or diagonal.
Consider how you might traverse the matrix. A nested loop is a common approach where the outer loop iterates through rows and the inner loop iterates through columns.
As you traverse, keep track of the current count of consecutive 1s. You can reset this count to zero whenever you encounter a 0.
Think about the different directions you need to check for consecutive 1s. You will need to handle horizontal and vertical lines first, then consider the two diagonal directions.
For horizontal lines, you can simply iterate through each row and count consecutive 1s. For vertical lines, you will need to iterate through each column.
When counting diagonal lines, remember that there are two types: from top-left to bottom-right and from bottom-left to top-right. You will need to implement separate logic for these.
Make sure to keep track of the maximum length of consecutive 1s you find as you iterate through the matrix. You can use a variable to store this maximum value.
Consider edge cases, such as matrices that are empty or contain only 0s. What should your function return in these cases?
Think about how you will return the result. The problem asks for the length of the longest line of consecutive 1s, so ensure your final output reflects that.
You are almost there! As you implement the logic, ensure that you check all four directions (horizontal, vertical, and both diagonals) and update your maximum length accordingly.

questionNotes: The matrix can be of any size, including empty.
The output should be a single integer representing the length of the longest line of consecutive 1s.
Consider all four directions: horizontal, vertical, and both diagonals.
Handle edge cases where the matrix may contain all zeros or be empty.
